36. So we must take care that our Brushes
can be somewhat more gracious and generous,
for good painting to flourish with us too.
Indeed, we must consider that the Painter
needs to work with as many colors
to paint a face, as one needs
green, blue, yellow and all varieties
to create a beautiful and pleasant Landscape.
left-middleA Painter needs as many colors to paint a face as a landscape.

37. Yet, we must gently blend all its colors,
so that the work is not hard or full of spots
but pleasant and with a swelling relief,
always imitating the best model in life,
which has inspired many good Painters.
Do not, like malicious Sectarians,
remain attached to your false opinions,
but play freely; it is no sin.

38. Do not persist in working in a poor manner.
You are not married to it; there is no shame
in deftly exchanging it for a better one.
Transforming for good is worthy of praise,
one gradually comes to a correct understanding.
Banish lamp-black in nudes;
aside from umber, permit yourself to use
asphaltum, Cologne earth, and terraverde.
left-middleOne must avoid lamp-black in nudes.

39. Lamp-black in dark areas can be passed over
easily in nudes–yes, cast it from your memory.
It will (says Vasari) severely discolor:
for Raphael, renowned in all the World’s domains,
in his last work, The Transfiguration
in San Pietro in Montorio, to his glory,
the colors appear to have been freshly painted,
as he had avoided lamp-black.
left-middleLamp-black discolors; for example, the panel by Raphael in Rome, at San Pietro in Montorio.

40. Over time, this black spoils the colors
with which it is mixed, and on the other hand,
produces greyness and not a glow;
it does not create the effect of flesh.
Since the sun, shining at all times,
gives the flesh a lively red blush,
some, to achieve this effect,
mix Massicot with their Flesh tone.

41. However, even if some fend for themselves,
everyone must follow the best path:
I think you need to avoid the Massicot
